passages.text: At turning points, it is natural to observe mixed signals
See our full research on Ecomomics: Brazil

- While business sentiment and credit growth are weak, consumer confidence and job growth are still solid- Inflation news was less upbeat, but we still see more disinflation; we lower year-end IPCA forecast to \(4.9\%\) - We continue to expect earlier and deeper interest rate cuts; watch for 2Q GDP and July IP next week- Fiscal results remain consistent with 2025 target; electoral polls were more mixed

While our call for deeper and earlier interest rate cuts remains alive, well, and unchanged, this week's data was more mixed compared to weeks past. Much of this discrepancy in the data, which appears to be a feature of the imbalances in the Brazilian economy, aligns with our view that an economic deceleration, but not a recession, is underway. However, two key variables for monetary policy showed that the core CPI disinflation process seems to have hit a bump in August and job growth is, at least up to July, only slowly decelerating.

New loans have fallen sharply in the three months through July, reaching the most negative growth rate in two years (Figure 1). This is happening despite a pickup in BNDES loans and an acceleration in new forms of private payroll- backed consumer loans. Credit standards are also worsening, with lending rates higher relative to last year, and the rate of non- performing loans at the highs of this cycle for both corporates and households. In other words, the tightening of monetary policy is working its way through the credit system.
Figure 1: IBC-Br ex-agro and credit growth
Source:BCB and J.P.Morgan

August business sentiment continued on the downward trajectory initiated this year. Manufacturing confidence has fallen again this month, accompanied by a weaker performance from retail sector sentiment, and services and construction sentiment are at their lowest levels in this cycle of expansion. Consumer confidence, which had been more depressed recently, is now moving up (Figure 2).
See page 6 for analyst certification and important disclosures.

While the disinflation process is probably helping to boost consumer sentiment, the perception of the labor market continues to improve. This is in stark contrast to what is happening to economic growth data, credit growth, and business sentiment.
Figure 2: Business and consumer confidence (FGV) - Actual
Source: FGV and J.P. Morgan

The main setback this week was the composition of the August CPI preview (IPCA- 15). While the headline aligned with our expectations, core IPCA- 15 stabilized at levels well above target. Core services, in particular, accelerated after months of slowdown (Figure 3). Also, this week's wholesale prices (IGP- M) stalled in their recent downward trajectory, primarily due to an unexpected rise in fresh food prices.

Job creation, while slowing from recent peaks, is only gradually moderating. This week's July formal jobs payroll (CAGED) decelerated to one of the slowest levels of the year (Figure 4), but this is a level still consistent with a falling unemployment rate in an already tight labor market.
Figure 3: Core IPCA-15 (CPI preview)
Source: IBGE, BCB and J.P. Morgan
Figure 4: Job growth %3m/3m, sa
Source:IBGE,Ministry of Labor,and J.P.Morgan

That said, we continue to be comfortable in our views on monetary policy and economic growth. Economic data continues to be consistent with a moderation in GDP growth in 2H25. We also remain confident that the headline and underlying measures of CPI will consistently decline throughout the second half of this year and into 2026. In fact, we have even further revised down our 2025 CPI forecast by a tenth of a point to \(4.9\%\) , reinforcing the case for our well below- consensus view of CPI at \(3.6\%\) by the end of next year. As a result, we reinforce our view of the BCB starting the easing cycle in December, lowering the policy rate below consensus and market pricing towards \(10.75\%\) by the end of 2026.

Next week's economic data releases will include the August PMIs, trade balance, vehicle production and sales, July industrial production (IP), and, most importantly, the 2Q GDP. We estimate that GDP growth moderated to \(1.8\% \mathrm{q} / \mathrm{qa}\) sair last quarter, following an agriculture- boosted \(5.7\%\) expansion in the first quarter. We anticipate that consumption will decelerate, yet remain robust, with the weakness in domestic final sales primarily driven by a decline in government consumption and a payback in investment. Regarding the July IP, we expect a slight \(0.1\% \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{m}\) decline at the beginning of 3Q.
Table 1: Real GDP growth %q/q saar
Source:IBGE and J.P.Morgan forecasts

This week we gain insights into the execution of the 2025 and the plans for the 2026 budget. The July fiscal results were anticipated to show a deterioration, driven by a worsening deficit due to the payment of nearly BRL 65 billion in court- ordered debt ("precatórios") and

increased execution of discretionary expenses. Although the results were slightly worse than expected, they remain consistent with our target-abiding estimate for a \(0.6\%\) of GDP primary deficit in 2025. As of this writing, the 2026 PLOA has not been unveiled, but indications suggest a maintenance of the ambitious \(+0.25\%\) of GDP target (JPM: \(- 0.5\%\) of GDP target-equivalent).

The focus, however, will increasingly shift away from 2025 execution and 2026 design, towards the economic policy mix from 2027 onwards—a debate inherently linked to the outcome of the October 2026 general election. On that front, recent polls present a mixed picture. While two national polls showed a marginal improvement in President Lula's approval ratings and electoral standing since June, another indicated a reversal of Lula's marginal lead against some potential candidates from the center-right spectrum. The shift underscores the volatility and competitiveness of the electoral race.
24Q425Q12Q25Tuesday - 2Gross domestic product%q/q saar0.25.71.8%oya nsa3.62.92.3May-25Jun-25Jul-25Wednesday - 3Industrial production%m/m sa-0.60.1-0.1%oya nsa3.3-1.30.3
Source:IBGE and J.P.Morgan forecasts

Brazil: Demand- related core CPI moved back up in July
Brazil: Recent CAD widening was primarily due to larger profit and dividend outflows
